I wonder if WEP has read "1984" by George Orwell.  In that classic novel, the all-knowing, all-powerful Big Brother dominates society because the Ministry of Fear knows the phobias and shames of everyone, and uses them to control and/or break any potential opponent; e.g., at the end of the book, Winston is made to love Big Brother by using his fear of insects to destroy his independence and sense of self.  So that is what we've come to -- the CIA/NSA and God-knows what other agencies will keep us safe by imitating the most heinous and amoral government ever imagined.  If that's O.K. for you, WEP, so be it.  But what a state we've come to; we need the Good Fascists to protect us from the Bad Fascists.  Do you understand what this means?  The terrorists have won, scaring us so badly that we give up our freedoms and morals in exchange for a presumed safety.  Ben Franklin had it right over 200 years ago; those who would trade their freedom for a bit of safety will end up with neither freedom nor safety.

Ah, Kipling, defender of the Raj and all that "white man's burden" rot. Surely, nothing could have changed in India since he died in 1936! Oh wait, India's population in 1936 was approximately 351 million, and was estimated by the Population Reference Bureau to be 1.3 billion in mid 2012, an increase of nearly 1 billion people or 3.6 times in just 76 years. Might that increase force more people to live in precarious places? Might it cause some people to cut down forests for timber and agricultural land in the headwaters areas that increases runoff thereby exascerbating flooding? And, I was not aware that Kipling was also a meteorologist that studied weather patterns over time. The weather is just randomly wandering first one way and then the other? Climate change is not forcing weather into new patterns? Oh, and this is happening in the DR too, only the numbers are smaller, but then, so is the island. Put down your Kipling long enough to read the morning newspaper.

It would be easier to buy into the "parent as friend" idea if parents were able to drop the parental role, which really is NOT a part of being a friend to one's child. Few parents can do this. (A friend does not function as a parent unless the relationship is one of mentor and mentee, perhaps.)

Since one is always a parent, that will be the dominant role no matter the child's age or maturity. (Thankfully, mature parents learn to treat their adult children as adults. Some, however, whether they realize it or not, continue to treat their adult offspring as children. This includes intelligent folks who should know better.)

Being friendly with one's offspring and socializing with them in areas of interest (beyond family-related events, etc.), when this exists between a parent and an offspring, can be lovely and rewarding for both. But let's be honest, it is rarer than people would like to admit and remains a fantasy for many parents.

A mindful parent to an adult child continues to hold a special and unique role in that child's life. Getting along, having genuine shared interests and activities, still does not make one that child's "friend." As someone here observed, often it's more one-sided (parent).

If you like and respect your child, show a healthy interest in their life and development, you will have a good relationship. Too many parents have come to expect more from their children as they become adults. This is not necessarily a good thing.

Those of us who've been there have known about "Incredible" India for some time. The question I always have is for the people who actually live there. The rest of Asia is quickly progressing from exotic destination to normal, developed place to live. Why isn't it a source of extreme annoyance to Indians themselves that India seems to stand still? Yes, they've built a subway, some malls, even a proper highway (more than 1)? Meanwhile look at what has happened in China.

I've lived in Kathmandu, Bangkok, Seoul and only in South Asia is the world more or less standing still. I know travelers who want it to stay that way and never want to see development happen in any of these places, India, Pakistan, Nepal. But I can't help thinking the people actually living there might want to live with something like a normal standard of living sometime this century. And I can't help wondering why they are not more upset or do not do more to make it so.
